clinicalSignificance.comment: The PAH variant c.1065+1G>A (IVS10+1G>A) affects the canonical splice site (donor site). Loss of function in the PAH gene is a known mechanism of disease. Exon skipping is predicted to not disrupt the reading frame. This variant is predicted to alter a region that is critical to protein function. The PAH variant c.1065+1G>A (IVS10+1G>A) was identified in two French patients with mild hyperphenylalaninemia (mHP, 180 < Phe < 600 μmol/L) with the likely pathogenic variant c.261C>A (p.Ser87Arg) and with the pathogenic variant c.1169A>G (p.Glu390Gly)(PMID: 26666653). The PAH variant c.1065+1G>A was also reported in an European patient with PAH deficiency (PMID: 10679941). According to gnomAD, the PAH variant c.1065+1G>A (IVS10+1G>A) is present at a low allele frequency in population databases, with the highest reported frequency in the European (Finnish) population (0.00005). In summary, this variant meets the criteria to be classified as likely pathogenic. PAH-specific ACMG/AMP criteria applied: PM2, PM3_Supporting, PP4, and PVS1_Strong.
